Posts.Content: Check out Holland & Barrett for the honey - until tomorrow they have it on their buy one get one for a penny deal - I got two 250g jars of the 24+ strength for Â£26.00 yesterday. I have had two cycles of EC chemo - first cycle my mouth ulcers were terrible, second not so bad but I still had them - have started with the honey this morning and hoping that next week when I have my third cycle I may not suffer at all.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo in 11 days.....

Posts.Content: You are more than welcome Starks - good luck with your first chemo - another recommendation from my own experience, even though you might be scared and not feel like it, try and eat a reasonable amount before your appointment - I was petrified, didnt eat all day and felt really sick after they gave me the anti sickness medication before they started with the chemo - second time I had a sandwich in the cafe at the hospital and felt fine but could have been because I wasn't as nervous, not sure.
Posts.Title: Starting chemo in 11 days.....

Posts.Content: Don't know if this will help but when I saw my surgeon for my post-op check up on Tuesday, he advised I keep using micro pore tape on my scars to help keep them flat and neat. So far it seems to be working, I don't have any irritation or additional soreness since having the dressings removed.
Posts.Title: Post Masectomy - Skin Puckering

Posts.Content: I didn't feel breathless as such but I always had a feeling of not being able to take a full deep breath if that makes sense - radiotherapy finished on 30th December and I am now back to normal - I did mention it to my radiotherapy team and they did say that it was a fairly common side effect x
Posts.Title: radiotherapy- breathlessness

Posts.Content: I had only been employed for 3 weeks on a temporary contract when I had my diagnosis and I have been lucky enough to keep my job - they have terminated my contract and set up a new one on a nil hours basis to allow me to work when I can instead of me having to commit to a fixed number of days/hours. I am still waiting for results but as my biopsy indicated I am triple negative, chemo is an almost definite for me even though my surgeon said my results may reveal different in which case chemo probably won't be needed, just radiotherapy. I am starting back next week, going to do 20 hours to start with working at home and play it by ear if chemo needed.
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and work

Posts.Content: Been this morning for a meeting with my consultant and my pre-op assessment. I have been told my cancer is triple negative and I am feeling scared to death at the moment. I don't seem to be able to find anything positive to read about triple negative so am just trying to process the information at the moment. I have been told my lymph nodes look fine and am taking it that this a positive sign - I just cannot believe how my life has changed in the last month. I have felt so positive through this and want to get my positivity back.
Posts.Title: Pre-op Assessment

Posts.Content: Thank you Hollyoskar - I have been on this forum since I was diagnosed on 17th April but from that day to this things seem to have changed so dramatically and this close to my surgery I wasn't expecting to have to deal with anything different. I have an amazing family but like me they are all struggling to cope with this 'new' information today. I won't let myself feel alone - I have a made a friend from this forum who has been a great support to me and do have a couple of friends that have suffered with breast cancer but not the triple negative.
Posts.Title: Pre-op Assessment

Posts.Content: I don't drive to chemo because I feel bit light headed afterwards but I do intend driving to radiotherapy appointments - my drive is only 15 mins for which I am extremely grateful - our car park is a joke and very expensive - the oncology car park is free but everyone parks in there regardless of which department they are visiting - totally not policed properly - best I don't rant too much about that one lol
Posts.Title: driving

Posts.Content: Hope you are feeling better today Genny - I feel extremely fortunate to have survived chemo only vomiting twice - I am extremely travel sick and had a terrible time in pregnancy - hope they can give you something next cycle to help relieve the symptoms xxx
Posts.Title: Post 1st chemo!

Posts.Content: I had long highlighted blonde hair which I had cut in stages and returned to my natural colour before chemo started. I found the waiting for it to happen much harder to deal with than when it actually did start to fall out. I didn't use the cold cap as I was told that as my hair was already thin on the top it would probably go anyway so didn't fancy the discomfort or the extra time at the chemo clinic to only delay what would probably happen whether or not I used it. Â I started to lose my hair at day 18 and about seven days after my second chemo I had lost it all - i didnt shave my head, I picked most of it out but there were some bits that clung fast so I left them - it helped me cope better. Â Once chemo was finished and my hair was showing signs of coming back, my daughter shaved all the longer bits off and now it is all growing from the same length :). Â
Posts.Title: Hair falling out!

Posts.Content: Not wishing to be controversial and definitely not criticising any treatment I have received, but does anyone think the additional chemo unit/staff time involved in use of the cold cap might influence how enthusiastic or otherwise the oncologists are when discussing the success of the cold cap ? Â I do get upset sometimes when I read that people have had success when I didn't even try or be encouraged to try and wonder if the staff had been a bit more positive about the results I could expect, I might have done. Â Just wondered what other people's thoughts are?Â
Posts.Title: Hair falling out!

Posts.Content: Just wanted to share the fact that I slept properly last night for the first time since I got my call back letter after my mammogram on 28th March. I don't think I have had more than 5 hours sleep any night since and hardly any since I was diagnosed last Thursday - I know my husband and mum have been worried about me not sleeping because I work away from home a lot and am due to be away two nights in a hotel on my own this week - at least I know I can relax about all of this and sleep now. Not counting my chickens but hopefully last night was a sign I am calming down about things.
Posts.Title: Sleep at last

Posts.Content: Hi Lorna - I am having a therapeutic mammoplasty on the right breast followed by chemo and radiotherapy before having the left breast matched up at the end of it all. Scared to death but trying to deal with it in small chunks at the moment - surgery first although I have had my hair cut quite a bit and will be getting it cut again in a week or so to get used to a shorter style - had long hair since my mid twenties so it's not been easy.
Posts.Title: Sleep at last

Posts.Content: Thank you Jane. My daughter has been talking to a friend at work who has been through this and she told her to tell me that I must think of this whole journey like being on a train. The carriages represent the different areas of my life e.g family, friends, work, home and my starting station is my surgery, the next station is my chemo and so on - I cannot get to the chemo station until I have been to the surgery station so I shouldn't try to go there in my head either. It made so much sense and has calmed me right down.
Posts.Title: Sleep at last

Posts.Content: I live about 30 miles from York but don't ever make the effort to go there enough :(. Hope you have a fab time, it's a lovely place to visit especially near Christmas - I second the Betty's Tearoom suggestion :)
Posts.Title: YAY!!

Posts.Content: I live about 30 miles from York but don't ever make the effort to go there enough :(. Hope you have a fab time, it's a lovely place to visit especially near Christmas - I second the Betty's Tearoom suggestion :)
Posts.Title: YAY!!

Posts.Content: So happy to be posting that I have survived 6 cycles of chemo and ready to move on to radiotherapy - planning scan and marking up being done on 17th November and sessions start 8th December, 15 to have and will be finished by the end of December - starting 2015 with all my treatment behind me :) This group has been such a massive help to me since I was diagnosed - thank you to everyone that has read and answered my questions. Â I will be continuing to join in the forum to help and support others as, without this group and the friends I have made through it, I think my journey would have been a totally different one xxx
Posts.Title: Finished Chemo !!!

Posts.Content: Thank you Jenny - it was touch and go whether I got the last one on time - my neutrophils had been very low at my blood test two days earlier and they said if it had been any other cycle than the last one, it would have been postponed but they said provided I didn't mind a wasted visit on Thursday then they would keep my slot open - glad I did because my bloods recovered to just above where they needed to be :)
Posts.Title: Finished Chemo !!!

Posts.Content: I have stopped reading stuff on the Internet about what I should and shouldn't eat - I take the view that now my treatment is nearly over if it is something I would avoid if watching my weight then either don't eat it or eat in moderation. Â I successfully lost 6 stone in 2013 eating low carb - I have struggled during chemo to maintain this and have gained more than I wanted to but I know I will lose it again
Posts.Title: DAIRY FOODS HIT BREAST CANCER RECOVERY

Posts.Content: I am having my second EC next Thursday - my side effects were all fairly manageable - the worst one was the sore mouth and ulcers - despite using prescribed mouth wash, the only thing that worked for me and cleared it up within a couple of days was a mild bicarbonate of soda mouth wash - eased the pain instantly. I will definitely be using it along side the prescribed mouth wash after second cycle.
Posts.Title: Shopping list for chemo - am I missing anything?

Posts.Content: I am having my second EC next Thursday - my side effects were all fairly manageable - the worst one was the sore mouth and ulcers - despite using prescribed mouth wash, the only thing that worked for me and cleared it up within a couple of days was a mild bicarbonate of soda mouth wash - eased the pain instantly. I will definitely be using it along side the prescribed mouth wash after second cycle.
Posts.Title: Shopping list for chemo - am I missing anything?

Posts.Content: My surgeon is lovely but I don't have the same feeling about my oncologist - definitely not crush material but then again, my husband is bald with a beard so maybe that's why lol lol (only kidding, I love my husband)
Posts.Title: Did anyone else develop a teensy consultant crush during their treatment...

Posts.Content: I am due to start chemo in the next couple of weeks although don't know yet what my chemo type will be - I was diagnosed triple negative stage 2 with no lymph node spread - I had long highlighted blonde hair that is now short with dark roots that are driving me nuts. I am desperate to keep my hair, mainly because I don't want the 50 shades of grey either lol but just not sure - I am going to be guided by the people at the hospital when I see them on Tuesday.
Posts.Title: cold cap??

Posts.Content: Great news - I too have triple negative and was very relieved that my SNB confirmed no lymph node involvement.
Posts.Title: Great News

Posts.Content: Good luck G em x
Posts.Title: cold cap??

Posts.Content: Thanks Mb77 - that's the reason I chose the reduction surgery - to try and avoid going back for surgery - I do have quite a large bust and have recently lost 6 stone in weight (intentional weight loss) so they said not only will it give them a better chance of clearing everything but also improve my appearance. Only down side is that because I need radiotherapy, I can't have both sides done at the same time - they reckoned about ten months to a year before left side can be done.
Posts.Title: Lymph Node Sentinel Test

Posts.Content: I am due to have a therapeutic mammoplasty on one breast for what I have been told is a grade 2, invasive cancer that is estrogen receptor negative. They have told me they will do the node sentinel test when I have my surgery and then if it is in the lymph nodes I will have another operation to remove the lymph nodes - some people I know that have been through this have said their test was done before the surgery. Has anyone else had the test done and had to then have a second operation?
Posts.Title: Lymph Node Sentinel Test

Posts.Content: Hi - thanks for the replies. The only results I have had so far is the biopsy results - no mention of any other tests except this node sentinel test. I have a ore-op assessment and an appointment with my consultant on Monday so hopefully might get more information then. They have already told me I will need chemo and radiotherapy because of the receptor negative but to be honest I am a bit overwhelmed by it all and just want to get the surgery over and then think about the next stage. I cannot change the diagnosis so the best thing I can do is take each step as it comes and then think about the next one when I have to.
Posts.Title: Lymph Node Sentinel Test

Posts.Content: Does node clearance mean another general anaesthetic.
Posts.Title: Lymph Node Sentinel Test

Posts.Content: I was told between 4 and 6 weeks by my oncologist last week so sounds a similar time frame. My last chemo is 6th November so I am hoping mine is 6 so that I get to enjoy Christmas before it starts ðŸ˜„
Posts.Title: after chemo

Posts.Content: Would be interesting to know people's thoughts on this - I have just finished chemo for Breast cancer and I have 7 root canal treated teeth - when my father died suddenly when I was 40, I went into shock and over a period of 2 years I developed serious dental problems - I was told that that the shock had probably caused this. Â Rather than have 7 teeth extracted and need dentures at 40/42, I suffered the root canal work - this post has got me wondering now.
Posts.Title: Root canal and cancer

Posts.Content: I had my second EC on Thursday - I found I had a strong metallic taste in my mouth while they they gave me the drugs so on my second cycle I took some chewy mints with me - this totally took the nasty taste away. Good luck for Tuesday x
Posts.Title: treatment starts Tuesday

Posts.Content: Well done JuJu - i am a couple of weeks behind you, my last session is due on 6th November and I cannot wait - got the radiotherapy still to have but I will approach that with the same positive attitude. Â l suffered terribly with mouth ulcers after my first session and was desperately looking for remedies - I also found Manuka honey and have taken it every single day since my second chemo and never had any mouth problems since - in fact I am so convinced it has had a positive effect on my health, I will be taking a small amount every day for the rest of my life :)
Posts.Title: Last chemo done, 3 x FEC and 3 x Taxatere. Done! finito!!

Posts.Content: Hi - I am on EC and will be on that for all sessions - have had 3, 3 left to go. Have lost all body hair but kept eyebrows/lashes and a small amount of head hair. It isn't such that I could go without a wig or headwear but if it is going to stay as it is, it will be a good start on re-growing if I wasn't to lose any more - my daughter is convinced I have more now than I had a month ago and was just wondering if anyone else had had their hair start to re-grow halfway through when on Epirubicin which is the drug my oncologist told me is the main one that causes the hair loss.
Posts.Title: Hair Re-growth

Posts.Content: I have lost all my bodily hair including my nasal hair - constantly running nose - attractive lol
Posts.Title: Hair Re-growth

Posts.Content: I am due my 4th EC chemo next week and haven't completely lost all of my head hair - what I have left is holding fast. From other people's experience, could this hair still go or is that likely to be as far as it will go. I wear a sleep cap at night and it's weeks since I found any hair in it. My daughter is convinced I now have more hair than I had a month ago. I didn't shave my head because I really couldn't cope with having it done all in one go and was prepared to lose it all bit by bit but now I am thinking I might not lose it all.
Posts.Title: Hair Re-growth

Posts.Content: Well I am convinced my hair is definitely growing back - my hair was naturally a mid brown but I have had it highlighted blonde for years - my hair now appears to be ginger and curly - I can see myself as little orphan Annie singing Tomorrow Tomorrow I'll Love Ya Tomorrow into a hairbrush before too long and just hope things get back to normal quickly lol ðŸ˜„
Posts.Title: Hair Re-growth
